was a person from Yin County, Ningbo.
He was proficient in both doctrinal studies and Chan practice, and his understanding was in accord with his practice.
He became a renowned monk of the time.
At first, he came from Fenglun on Mount Tiantai.
He ascended to become the abbot of Baotuo.
He guided the assembly in teaching the Dharma, revived the temple's income, and revitalized the monastic community.
In the spring of the Gengxu year of the Hongwu era, Liu Jun, the envoy of the Ministry of Rites in Zhejiang, traveled with the master from west to east.

3. Biography of Shi Yuanzhen, Monk of Xingsheng Temple in Songjiang. Shi Yuanzhen, also known as Yongzang,
was a son of the Zhu family in Shanghai, Songjiang.
He left home and received full ordination at Xingsheng Temple, where he studied the Tiantai teachings and meditation.
His precepts were pure and his knowledge was vast.
He diligently practiced the Lotus Sutra and Amitabha Repentance.ğŸ”½In his spare time, he wrote the Lotus Sutra and various sutras.
He expounded the Dharma according to conditions and sat in meditation until dawn.
In the second year of Hongwu, he fell slightly ill.
He bathed, wrote a verse to inform the assembly, and said:
For forty-two years,
there was no practice and no cultivation.
There was birth and there was death.
The great ocean is just a single bubble.
True return is no return.
The mind is empty and pure, wandering freely.
He sat in full lotus position and passed away peacefully.
4. Biography of Shi Huirui, Monk of Shangtiantong Temple in Hangzhou. Shi Huirui was called Dongming.
He was a son of the Tiantai Jia family.
He was a descendant of Jia Sidao, the prime minister of the Song dynasty.
When Sidao was exiled, the master was still young.
He aspired to become a monk and relied on Master Pingshan of Guangyan Temple in the county.
After several years, he shaved his head and received full ordination.
At the age of twenty-two, he heard that Baizi Ting was lecturing on Tiantai teachings in Chicheng. The master went to his seat.
Before long, he was able to grasp the great meaning.
Baizi Ting sighed and said,
Throwing a ball on a steep slope is not enough to compare with the speed of his understanding.
Will my way greatly flourish through him?
From then on, the master's learning became more profound and his reputation became great in one generation.
One day, he took a nap.
He vaguely saw bamboo lying on the ground, with white porridge congealing on the bamboo.
The master lay on the ground and ate it.
After waking up, he told Baizi Ting about it.
Ting explained, saying,
Bamboo and porridge have the same sound.
You got to eat the porridge on the ground.
It is probably not a coincidence that you are destined to be in the upper or lower Tianzhu.
He then crossed the Qiantang River and visited Chan Master Zhuwu Jing at Shangzang.
The room he was staying in was rather low and damp.
So he wrote a poem about it.
Chan Master Zhuwu saw the poem and said to the assembly:
This child is extraordinary.
In the future, he will be the abbot of this mountain.
He cannot be dismissed because of his young age.
So he treated him as a guest and friend.
Soon, he was appointed to the guest reception office and later took charge of the monks' records.
When Chan Master Zhuwu passed away, Chan Master Zhantang Cheng succeeded him as abbot.
He appreciated Chan Master Wuming and invited him to the rear hall.
After more than a year, he left to be the abbot of Shengshui on Mount Wu.
In the fourth year of the Zhizheng era of the Yuan dynasty, he became the abbot of Jinfeng.
After three years, Tianzhu suffered a disaster.
Yuanchen Gao Nalin invited Chan Master Wuming to rebuild it.
The temple buildings were completed, and Wang Yan wrote a record for it.
In the fourth year, he moved to Shangzang.
Chan Master Wuming knew that his fate was there and was diligent day and night.
He completely repaired everything in the temple.
The Yuan Emperor Shun heard of him and specially bestowed the title of Compassionate Light, Wonderful Response, and Universal Salvation
And a golden-threaded robe to honor him.
In the sixteenth year, he retired and secluded himself in the mountains and valleys of Mount Tiantai in Zhejiang.
No one recognized him.
The Yuan prime minister Darishan sent an envoy
To search for him and invited him back to the mountain.
He resided at Upper Tianzhu for twenty-five years in total.
In the second year of Hongwu in the great Ming Dynasty, the emperor ordered him to attend the Buddhist assembly at Mount Jianguo.
He ordered the Ministry of Rites to provide meals.
The next day, he summoned him to the Fengtian Palace.
The hundred officials all gathered, and the monks were like a school of fish.
Only the master, being the oldest in age with ruddy complexion and white eyebrows, was placed in the front row. The emperor personally asked about the way to rescue and liberate the suffering beings.
The master fully explained it, and the emperor was delighted. The Taizu looked at the assembly of monks and said:
In recent years, those who study Buddhism only eat well, relax, and waste their years.
The Diamond Sutra, Lankavatara Sutra, and Heart Sutra are all essential for concentrating the mind.
Why not thoroughly investigate its meaning?
Those who do not understand it now should ask the Dharma Master Bai Mei.
Later, when summoned to see the Taizu, he was only called Bai Mei and not by his name.
Once, together with the Dharma Master Bie Feng and the Chan Master Jin Bi Feng, they were given food in the inner palace.

They reported that Wa Guan Temple was where the Sui Dynasty Chan Master Shi Fa Hua of Tian Tai School lectured on the Lotus Sutra, and it should not be abandoned. The Taizu ordered a separate building to be constructed at Tian Jie to preserve its traces.
The edict ordered him to open the mountain and expound the Dharma.
In the fifth year, in the first month of spring, he again held a grand water and land ritual on Zhong Mountain.
He was ordered to expound the Vinaya precepts, and the Taizu personally led the hundred officials to listen.
After the event was completed, he took leave to return to Shang Zhu.
On the day of resigning from the abbot's position, he performed the Amitabha Repentance to attain pure practices.
In the twelfth year, on the first day of the seventh month in autumn, he dreamed one night.
A blue lotus flower grew in a square pond, with its fragrance permeating the surroundings.
When he woke up, he told the assembly, saying:
The auspicious signs of my rebirth in the Pure Land are now evident.
In the human world, it is almost not far away.
Four days later, he sat in the lotus position, joined his palms, and passed away.
His worldly age was eighty-nine.
His years as a monk were seventy-three.
Ten days later, his entire body was enshrined in the Miaoying Pagoda in the west peak of the temple.
The master's physical body was tall and majestic.
His eyebrows were over an inch long.
The pupils of his eyes gleamed and shot out at people.
But people, whether old or young, saw the master enter the city.
They all called out:
Here comes our White Eyebrowed Venerable!
They competed to hold incense and flowers to scatter upon him.
The master's face was stern and cold, and he never spoke idly.
He never uttered a soft flattering word when facing kings, officials, or ministers.
As for guiding and inspiring later students, his words and demeanor were as gentle as the spring sun.
Therefore, many people were delighted to follow his teachings.
Those who succeeded him in inheriting the Dharma included Si Ji, Xing Chu, Yun Jian, Yun Zhong, Liang Jin, Pu Zhi, Wen Hui, Yuan Xiu, Jing Fan, and several others.

In the twentieth year, he moved to serve as the abbot of Jingde.
In the last years of the Yuan dynasty, the world was in great turmoil with warfare.
People all thought of hiding themselves.
The master alone focused his mind on temple affairs.
He did not change his resolve due to the difficulties of the times.
His conduct of promoting goodness and reprimanding evil changed people's views.
He accepted the pure assembly and lectured on the sutras and commentaries every day.
There was not a moment of leisure.
When the great Ming dynasty was established, the seat of Jingshan was vacant.
The prefect Li invited him to expound the teachings.
After a few days, he received an imperial decree.
It ordered the abbots of the famous monasteries in the east and west of Zhejiang to all gather in the capital.
Together they built Tianjie and established the Shanshi Institute.
Using it to unify the monks and jointly supervise the work.
The elders of all directions did not know what to do.
The master alone came up with a plan that was well-organized.
At that time, the hundred thousand people all followed his method.
On the sixteenth day of the sixth month of that year, he knew the time of his death was approaching.
He summoned his disciples and entrusted them with his later affairs.
On the seventeenth day, he sat peacefully and passed away.
He lived to be forty-six years old.
He was twenty-eight years old when he became a monk.
His disciples Yuanjue, Yindian, Shengyuan, Kefu, and others cremated his body.
They built a stupa to the south of the stupa of Dharma Master Biancai at Longjing.
The master's bearing was elegant, his discussions were magnanimous, he upheld the right path and did not cater to the vulgar crowd.
Whenever he was asked about various temples, he planted disciples everywhere, and those who followed him became his enemies.
The master then vowed not to shave and accept disciples.
Students came to follow him.
He would always sternly refuse them.

His body was tall and upright, and his speech was beautiful.

He only recited the Huayan Sutra as his regular practice.

Like Duan Jiang En, a student of Shaolin, he was recommended to be the abbot of Tianyi.

He then prepared a sumptuous meal and leisurely gave it to him, saying,

I have heard that he is a famous virtuous monk in the Chan forest.
If you people are going to harm him,
how can gentlemen do such a thing?

The master was extremely filial and hated that his father had died too early.
Whenever it was the anniversary of his mother's death, he would inevitably shed tears uncontrollably.
He raised his mother with utmost purity and sincerity.
Not only did he follow her with a cool and warm countenance,
but he also made sure that she tasted the flavor of the Way in her heart.
Even after his mother passed away, he never neglected her.
Moreover, he sought out famous scholars to write an account of her life and erected a stone monument beside her grave.
The master upheld the precepts with utmost strictness, having nothing extra outside of his single alms bowl.
He only had over five thousand scrolls of books and histories.
In the twelfth month of the second year of the Hongwu era, he showed signs of slight illness.
